metadata.title: Fragile X Syndrome  Speech Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: The brain; can also affect facial features, joints, head circumference, feet and testicles in male patients
description: Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is a common hereditary neurological disease that causes intellectual disability (ID), as well as physical, behavioral, and sensory deficits.(2) FXS, also known as Martin-Bell  syndrome or Escalante's syndrome, is associated with a mutation of a gene on the X chromosome, thereby affecting males more often and more severely than females.(2) FXS is the most common inherited cause of ID and the second most common genetic cause of ID after Down syndrome.(7) FXS is a congenital disease that does not significantly alter life expectancy; hence, although most patients are initially evaluated during early childhood, it is possible for a patient with FXS to present for speech therapy as an adult(4)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients with FXS have cognitive as well as physical symptoms. During early childhood, the physical symptoms are less noticeable, but they become more prominent during and after puberty(1)

Cognitive deficits/weakness  (moderate to severe intellectual disability in males; absent to mild intellectual disability in females)(1) –Anxiety(1)  –Attention deficit and behavioral inhibition in young males (especially sustained attention and inhibitory control deficits)(1,2) –Developmental delay/ID(1) –Aberrant face and gaze avoidance/habituation –Hyperactivity (ADHD)(1,2) –Hyperarousal(1,2) –Impaired sequential processing of information(2) –General impaired working memory(2) –Manifestations of aggressive outbursts/self-injurious  or abusive behaviors(6,7) –Extreme shyness(1) –Speech and language deficits(1)

Cognitive strengths:  Patients with FXS will have areas of relative cognitive strength. These areas might still be delayed when compared to chronologically age-matched  peers:(2) –Strong long-term  visual memory(2) –Simultaneous processing and achievement(2)

Physical symptoms –Facial dysmorphia(1) -Long face(1) -Large, protruding ears(1) -Prominent chin/jaw(1) –Hyperflexible joints(1) –Macrocephaly (defined as increased head circumference)(1) –Macro-orchidism  (abnormally large testicles)(1) –Mild delay of developmental milestones(1) –Pes planus (flat foot)(1) –Prominent forehead(1) –Tall stature(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Children with FXS sometimes respond to changes in routine and/or new or unfamiliar persons with overt displays of anxiety, including repetitive/self-injurious  behavior;(6) for an evaluation of a child’s speech and language abilities, the child’s parent or primary caregiver should always be available to provide additional information and/or support as needed
Cultural competency must be used when assessing and treating speech, language, and cognitive functioning
It is important to review medical history and reports from other disciplines (e.g., neuropsychology) before conducting a speech-language  evaluation or treatment

causes: fxs is caused by the mutation o: “Fragile” sites are areas on chromosomes that have a tendency to break or separate(8)–The gene associated with FXS is located on one such fragile site on the distal long arm of chromosome Xq27.3(8)
risk factors: Sex (males at higher risk than females)(1,2,6)
Family history of FXS or ID(1,4)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was FXS diagnosed in the patient? -Diagnosis of FXS is confirmed by molecular DNA testing in clinical practice(41) -Review medical history and physical from patient’s pediatrician or primary care physicianFor pediatric patients -Was the child a quiet or vocal infant? -Did the child coo, babble, or imitate sounds as an infant? -At what age did these behaviors begin? -When did the child say his or her first word? -Typically developing children acquire their first words at around 12 months of age(2) -First word acquisition may be delayed in children with FXS(2) -At what age did the child begin to name objects or persons? -At what age did the child start to put words together (e.g., “Daddy up”)? -Were the child’s first words easy or difficult to understand? -Currently, what specific sounds does the child make? -Which sounds or words are hard to understand? -How does the child communicate wants and needs? -Does the child use gesture or other means to communicate?For pediatric patients -Did the child’s mother have any illnesses, accidents, or complications while pregnant with the child? -Did the mother take any medications during the pregnancy? -What was the length of the pregnancy with the child? -What was the duration of the delivery? -What was the child’s weight at birth? -Were there any complications or unusual circumstances during birth or shortly after? -What was the Apgar score?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of FXS typically involves medications to manage behavioral symptoms such as attention deficit and anxiety(9)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Serotonin agents (to control frequent temper outbursts/tantrums)(7) Carbamazepine or valproic acid(7) Fluoxetine(7) Central nervous system stimulants (to improve symptoms of attention/reduce hyperactivity [ADHD])(7) Clonidine(7) In a preliminary trial conducted in Canada in which the medication regimens of 20 individuals with FXS (ages 1332 years) were supplemented with minocycline (broadspectrum  tetracycline antibiotic), researchers found that the drug was welltolerated  and provided significant functional benefits in terms of reduced aberrant behaviors; researchers recommended a placebocontrolled trial(49)  In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled,  crossover trial conducted in the United States with 55 children with FXS (ages 3.5 years to 16 years; 48 participants completed the full trial), researchers found that minocycline treatment for 3 months led to significantly greater global improvement as compared to a placebo. Because treatment lasted only 3 months, researchers recommended longer controlled clinical trials to further investigate benefits, intolerable side effects, and safety of minocycline(40) Case studies have reported increased linguistic communication ability in patients with FXS following the introduction of acamprosate (calcium acetylhomotaurine) as part of the medicinal treatment of FXS(10)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
To be completed by qualified psychiatrist or neuropsychologist(1)
May include IQ testing (Stanford-Binet; Wechsler Intelligence Scales for Children-Revised [WISC-R])(1,6)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there certain times of day that the patient’s communication is better or worse? -Does the patient speak more clearly or communicate more effectively with certain people or in certain situations?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Patients over the age of 50 who are carriers of the FXS premutation are at higher risk for developing FXS-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS).(4) Approximately 40% of males with the FXS premutation develop FXTAS(36) -Women with the FXS premutation can have FXS-associated  primary ovarian insufficiency (FXPOI), a problem with ovarian function that can lead to premature ovarian failure (POF) and early menopause (prior to age 40)(4)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula? Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? Does the patient require ventilator support?Document any behavioral symptoms that could indicate psychosocial disturbances -Perseverative and stereotyped maladaptive behaviors (rituals/insistence) are commonly observed in individuals with FXS.(39) Stereotyped behaviors are actions that are repetitive and rigid. Examples are hand flapping, body rocking, toe walking, spinning objects, sniffing, immediate and delayed echolalia, and running objects across one’s peripheral vision -Highly social situations can increase forms of social avoidance, anxiety, and gaze aversion behaviors in FXS patients -Research suggests that patients with FXS avoid eye contact and stressful social situations because of an overactive sympathetic nervous system as well as an underactive parasympathetic nervous system, resulting in physical distress from social engagement(43) -Patients with FXS have emotion recognition deficits—specifically, an inability to recognize angry and neutral emotional facial expressions—which might account for some of their difficulty in social situations(32) -In a study conducted in the United States with 118 male toddlers with FXS, researchers found that the boys exhibited significant delays in adaptive behavior development (as measured by the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales). Additionally, adaptive behavior delays were greater as the patients’ ages increased. The greatest areas of weakness for the boys with FXS in this study were motor and daily living adaptive skills(33) -Patients with FXS sometimes engage in self-injurious/abusive  behavior, especially when they are upset or anxious(6) -Mothers of children with FXS are at increased risk for caregiving stress, poor psychosocial health problems, and physical ailments (e.g., headaches, muscle soreness, fatigue) compared to mothers of children without disabilities(28,29)Document hearing ability/loss; recurrent otitis media is significantly more common in patients with FXS(1)  -Document if the patient has had recurrent otitis media, as this has been found to exacerbate the language deficits already inherent to FXS(35) -For detailed information on the effects of otitis media on speech and language, see Clinical Review…Hearing Loss,Effects on Speech and Language ; Item Number -A hearing screening with an audiometer is within the scope of practice of a SLP and should be performed with speech and language evaluations for FXS patients. If the patient fails the hearing screening, a referral to pediatric audiology should be made for a full comprehensive audiological diagnostic evaluation(1) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of FXS or other ID in the patient’s family? As FXS is a hereditary disease, history of ID is reported in up to 75% of families of patients with FXS(1)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient or family member about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and/or pervasive developmental disorders frequently co-occur  in patients with FXS.(1,2,13) (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of children with ASD, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic) In a study comparing 23 male subjects with a diagnosis of FXS+ASD to a group of 38 male subjects with a diagnosis of ASD, researchers found that both groups exhibited similar rates of stereotypic behaviors, selfinjury,  and sameness behaviors. The scores for the boys with FXS+ASD indicated less severe (significantly lower) presentation of thecompulsive/repetitive and ritual behaviors, gaze integration, quality of social overtures, responsive social smiles, facial expressions, and response to joint attention/ name(37) Other researchers believe that the language development and motor milestones profile is very different in those with FXSonly  and those with coexisting FXS and ASD; they also believe that coexisting FXS+ASD should be classified as a distinct phenotype of FXS(25,37) Common co-occurring  conditions include attention-deficit/hyperactivity  disorder (ADHD), seizures, frequent recurrent otitis media (middle ear infections), and mitral valve prolapse (MVP)(1,7)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or family about other symptoms the patient is experiencing Document if and when the child has had ear infections How long did the ear infections last? How frequently did the child have ear infections? Does the child presently have an ear infection?

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any For pediatric patients, what interests, hobbies, or other activities does the child have? For adults, what type of interests, hobbies, employment, or other activities does the patient have?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment Does the patient use a walker, wheelchair, or leg braces? Does the patient have a hearing loss? Does the patient require/wear hearing aids or have cochlear implants? Does the patient require/wear glasses? Does the patient require assistance to perform ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (e.g., caregivers, siblings)? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? What languages is the patient exposed to at home, school, and/or work? -What percentage of time is each language spoken around/to the patient?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with FXS will present with cognitive deficits such as impaired memory (especially working memory) and attention skills.(1,15)Refer to neuropsychological reports for complete information regarding patient’s cognition –In a study conducted in the United States with 13 male infants with FXS, researchers found and identified that the infants displayed aberrant visual attention compared to typically developing infants (as measured by gaze duration, latency to look away) at 9, 12, and 18 months of age(30) –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 37 boys ranging in age from 4 to 10 years with confirmed diagnoses of FXS, researchers found that the boys with FXS demonstrated obvious difficulties in attention to visual stimuli as well as poor responses to auditory stimuli as compared to typically developing boys. Additionally, researchers found that the typically developing children benefited from having new information presented bimodally (e.g., a picture and a verbal description); however, the boys with FXS did not. This finding suggests that either the boys with FXS have difficulty binding the auditory and visual attention measures/information together or they are unable to processes multimodal inputs effectively(31) –Older patients presenting with FXTAS sometimes also present with significantly impaired executive functioning and/or working memory(11,16,47) –The rate of progression of cognitive deficits/impairment associated with FXTAS dementia seem to worsen with increasing

other: Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for dysphagia; follow recommended protocols for swallowing safety and post feeding instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that the patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for dysphagia and educated about safe feeding strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Speech therapy for patients with FXS will focus on speech, language, and/or cognitive-linguistic  deficits. Specific goals will be determined following a thorough evaluation by a licensed and certified SLP. Speech and language therapy should be one aspect of a multidisciplinary treatment approach to treating an individual with FXS(1) treatment   (4) _ For detailed information on therapy for stuttering, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicProgression will vary according to patient deficits and goalsNone specified; as with any speech therapy, greater progress is anticipated with home practice; to be determined by speech therapist based on individual Dysphagia (as needed) Increase swallow safety Dysphagia therapy _ Therapy will vary according to the results of a swallow evaluation. Treatment may include strategies for airway protection, strategies for facilitating oral phase of swallowing, and dietary adjustments. (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic)Progression will vary according to patient deficits and goalsHome program will vary with respect to the goals of the patient  .
assessment plan of care.rule out: It is possible for a patient to be affected by FXS in conjunction with other types of congenital or neurological disorders. In order to provide the best possible treatment, the patient’s medical team will attempt to rule out the following diagnoses before making a diagnosis of FXS: Angelman syndrome(5) Prader-Willi  syndrome (PWS)(5) Rett syndrome(5) Sotos syndrome(5)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: The following referrals might be appropriate for patients with FXS Refer to physical and occupational therapy if the patient has reduced mobility, difficulty with ADLs, or difficulty with sensory integration(7) –Physical and occupational therapy for older patients who present with FXTAS(11) Refer to neurologist if the patient has not already undergone neurological and/or neuropsychological examination(1,7) Refer to ophthalmologist if additional vision problems are noted or reported by the patient and/or caregiver during physical examination(1) Refer to audiologist and/or otolaryngologist if the patient fails the hearing screening and/or appears to have difficulty hearing during the diagnostic audiologic evaluation(1)  Refer to psychiatrist/neurologist/developmental pediatrician for further assessment if ASD is suspected(13) Refer to learning disabilities specialist if parents of a child with FXS report difficulty in school subjects(14) Due to the unique challenges of caring for a child with FXS or FXS with ASD, parents may exhibit depression and/or anxiety(21,22) –Referral to psychiatrist, psychologist, or family counseling might be appropriate if patient’s parents describe difficulty coping with stress, hopeless thoughts, and/or depression –The families of children with FXS experience significant financial and employment burdens; consideration for these burdens and referrals to local and national resources and support programs are often necessary(23)
treatment summary: In a study conducted in France that compared implicit procedural learning in individuals with FXS or Down syndrome to age-matched, typically developing controls, researchers found that the ability to learn a sequence of 6 blocks implicitly was relatively efficient for the FXS group(24) –Learning decreased as the number of blocks to remember increased(24) –Researchers recommended attempting to use intact implicit learning (cognitive) skills and procedures to teach new information to individuals with FXS(24)

Joint engagement –In a study conducted in the United States with 28 toddlers with FXS and their mothers, researchers investigated the amount of time the dyads participated in joint engagement activities. Joint engagement with a caregiver around an object is considered coordinated joint engagement if the child and caregiver are attending to the same object and they are both mutually involved. In supported joint engagement they are both attending, but the child is not actively responding to the caregiver about the object. In the study, the toddlers with FXS spent more overall time in supported joint engagement compared to coordinated joint engagement. Researchers found that more time spent in coordinated joint engagement was associated with higher language abilities in these toddlers with FXS. Researchers concluded that early intervention programs targeting increased coordinated joint engagement might lead to increased language abilities in children with FXS over time(48)

Maternal responsivity –Maternal responsivity is defined as a “healthy, growth-producing  relationship characterized by warmth, nurturance, and stability as well as specific behaviors, such as contingent positive responses to child initiations.”(38) With respect to language development, high levels of maternal responsivity would be characterized by the mother of a child using frequent verbal input, responding to the child’s intentional communication attempts (e.g., imitations, expansion), and following the child’s interests (e.g., the child picks up a train and the mother states, “Look! You’re going to play with that train!”(38) –In a study conducted in the United States with 55 mother-child  dyads, researchers investigated the relationship between maternal responsivity and child vocabulary development in children with FXS. Communication interactions between the mothers and their children were observed and coded over the course of 7 years. At the start of the study, the children ranged in age from 11 months to 4 years old. Researchers found that sustained maternal responsivity over time was a significant predictor of the number of different words in the child’s vocabulary at age 8. Although this was not an intervention study, the researchers discussed the implications for intervention. Because prior intervention studies have shown that parents can be taught to be more responsive, parent training in responsivity might improve vocabulary development in children with FXS(38) . maintenance or prevention: There is no way to prevent FXS; however, genetic counseling and screening are available to confirm diagnosis as well as provide information to parents prior to the birth of a child with FXS.(5,46) Cascade testing involves testing relatives of a person known to be affected by FXS to determine if family members are also carriers of genetic mutations(46)

The American College of Medical Genetics recommends that testing for the FXS genetic mutation should be considered for the following individuals:(5) Males and females with ID, developmental delay, or ASD, especially if they have: –Physical symptoms of FXS –A family history of FXS –Relatives with ID of an unknown origin Fetuses of known FXS carrier mothers –In a DNA study conducted in the United States in which researchers analyzed 17 pedigrees of patients with FXS, only 8 of the cases presented with a family history of ID or FXS -Examination of the other 9 pedigrees revealed family histories of ADHD, ASD, speech/hearing deficits, and/or behavioral disorders -The authors of this study propose that FXS carrier testing should be expanded to pregnant women with family history that includes these additional risk factors Couples seeking reproductive counseling with: –Family history of FXS –Family history of ID of unknown origin –Fertility problems related to elevated FSH levels -Especially given a family history of premature ovarian failure, FXS or ID Individuals who have been found to have a fragile X site on chromosome analysis Patients with late onset tremor or cerebellar ataxia of unknown origin –Especially if there is family history of FXS, ID, or movement disorders
